Expectation1: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation1: The carpenter should be on time in the work area
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: At a communal event, the catered dishes lack certification and substituting food would be difficult.
Story: I arrived at the construction site just as the sun was rising, my toolbox heavy in my hand. The foreman’s words echoed in my mind: “Be on time, follow every safety rule—no exceptions.” I took pride in my work, in the careful way I measured and cut, always alert to the dangers around me. Today, though, there was a communal lunch for the crew, a rare treat. As I glanced at the spread, my heart sank. None of the food was kosher, and there was no way to substitute or prepare my own meal. My stomach grumbled, but the thought of breaking my dietary laws made me uneasy. The foreman called everyone over, urging us to eat quickly so we could get back to work on schedule. If I hesitated, I’d risk being late and possibly endangering myself or others by rushing. But if I ate, I’d be betraying a core part of my faith. I stood there, torn, the expectations of my job and my beliefs pulling me in opposite directions.
